title: Physics
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this section, you will be able to:

Calculate position vectors in a multidimensional displacement problem.
Solve for the displacement in two or three dimensions.
Calculate the velocity vector given the position vector as a function of time.
Calculate the average velocity in multiple dimensions.


These are the key skills and concepts we will cover today. We’ll start with position and displacement, then move on to velocity.

title: Physics
text:
Introduction to Multidimensional Motion

Motion in 2D and 3D extends 1D definitions.
Requires vector algebra, not scalar algebra.
Essential for describing complex trajectories.


In one dimension, we could describe motion using just numbers, positive or negative. Now, with multiple dimensions, direction becomes crucial, so we must use vectors. This allows us to describe more realistic motions like a ball thrown through the air or a satellite orbiting Earth.

title: Physics
text:
Coordinate Systems and Position Vectors

To describe motion, first establish a coordinate system (x, y, z).
Particle location: \(P(x, y, z)\).
Coordinates are functions of time: \(x = x(t)\) \(y = y(t)\) \(z = z(t)\)


Just like in 1D, where we picked an origin, in 2D or 3D, we need a coordinate system. We typically use Cartesian coordinates \((x, y, z)\). As the particle moves, its coordinates change over time.

title: Physics
text:
The Position Vector

Vector from origin to point \(P(x, y, z)\).
Represented as \(\vec{r}(t)\).
In unit vector notation: \[\vec{r}(t) = x(t)\hat{i} + y(t)\hat{j} + z(t)\hat{k}\]




Figure 4.2: A 3D coordinate system with position vector \(\vec{r}(t)\)







Note


Right-Handed Coordinate System
This orientation (x out, y right, z up) is used throughout the chapter.





The position vector \(\vec{r}(t)\) points from the origin to the particle’s location at any given time \(t\). We use unit vectors \(\hat{i}\), \(\hat{j}\), and \(\hat{k}\) to denote the x, y, and z directions, respectively. The image shows a typical right-handed coordinate system. If you curl the fingers of your right hand from the positive x-axis to the positive y-axis, your thumb will point in the direction of the positive z-axis.

title: Physics
text:
Displacement Vector in 3D

Change in position of a particle.
From initial position \(\vec{r}(t_1)\) to final position \(\vec{r}(t_2)\).
Calculated as: \[\Delta\vec{r} = \vec{r}(t_2) - \vec{r}(t_1)\]




Figure 4.3: Displacement vector \(\Delta\vec{r}\) from \(P_1\) to \(P_2\)







Important


Displacement is a vector quantity! It represents the straight-line distance and direction between two points, regardless of the path taken.





Displacement is not the same as total distance traveled. It’s simply the difference between the final and initial position vectors. Think of it as “as the crow flies.” This is a vector subtraction, so we subtract the corresponding components.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Polar Orbiting Satellite (1/2)
A satellite orbits Earth at an altitude of 400 km. What is the displacement vector from the North Pole to \(-45^\circ\) latitude? (Radius of Earth = 6370 km)
Strategy:

Visualize the problem graphically.
Use unit vectors to calculate displacement.


This example helps us apply the displacement vector concept. We’ll set up a coordinate system and define the initial and final positions using unit vectors, then perform the vector subtraction.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Polar Orbiting Satellite (2/2)
Solution:

Orbit radius \(R = 6370 \text{ km} + 400 \text{ km} = 6770 \text{ km}\).
North Pole is at \(90^\circ\) latitude (along positive y-axis).
Initial position vector: \(\vec{r}(t_1) = 6770 \hat{j} \text{ km}\)
Final position at \(-45^\circ\) latitude (below x-axis): \(\vec{r}(t_2) = 6770 (\cos(-45^\circ))\hat{i} + 6770 (\sin(-45^\circ))\hat{j} \text{ km}\) \(\vec{r}(t_2) = 4787\hat{i} - 4787\hat{j} \text{ km}\)
Displacement vector: \(\Delta\vec{r} = \vec{r}(t_2) - \vec{r}(t_1)\) \(\Delta\vec{r} = (4787\hat{i} - 4787\hat{j}) - (6770\hat{j})\) \(\Delta\vec{r} = 4787\hat{i} - 11,557\hat{j} \text{ km}\)
Magnitude: \(|\Delta\vec{r}| = \sqrt{(4787)^2 + (-11,557)^2} = 12,509 \text{ km}\)
Direction: \(\theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-11,557}{4787}\right) = -67.5^\circ\) (south of east)


Figure 4.4: Satellite orbit visualization

Figure 4.5: Displacement vector components

First, we define our coordinate system with the North Pole along the y-axis. The total radius for the satellite’s orbit is the Earth’s radius plus the altitude. Then we find the components of the initial and final position vectors. Remember that negative angles are measured clockwise from the positive x-axis. Finally, we subtract the vectors component-wise to get the displacement, then calculate its magnitude and direction. Note that the path taken by the satellite is curved, but the displacement is a straight line.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Brownian Motion
A particle undergoes Brownian motion with the following displacements (in \(\mu m\)):
\(\Delta\vec{r}_1 = 2.0\hat{i} + \hat{j} + 3.0\hat{k}\)
\(\Delta\vec{r}_2 = -\hat{i} + 3.0\hat{k}\)
\(\Delta\vec{r}_3 = 4.0\hat{i} - 2.0\hat{j} + \hat{k}\)
\(\Delta\vec{r}_4 = -3.0\hat{i} + \hat{j} + 2.0\hat{k}\)
What is the total displacement from the origin?
Solution:
Sum the individual displacement vectors:
\(\Delta\vec{r}_{Total} = \Delta\vec{r}_1 + \Delta\vec{r}_2 + \Delta\vec{r}_3 + \Delta\vec{r}_4\)
\(\Delta\vec{r}_{Total} = (2.0 - 1.0 + 4.0 - 3.0)\hat{i} + (1.0 + 0 - 2.0 + 1.0)\hat{j} + (3.0 + 3.0 + 1.0 + 2.0)\hat{k}\)
\(\Delta\vec{r}_{Total} = 2.0\hat{i} + 0\hat{j} + 9.0\hat{k} \text{ }\mu m\)
Magnitude:
\(|\Delta\vec{r}_{Total}| = \sqrt{(2.0)^2 + (0)^2 + (9.0)^2} = \sqrt{4 + 81} = \sqrt{85} \approx 9.2 \text{ }\mu m\)
Direction (with respect to x-axis in xz-plane): \(\theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{9}{2}\right) \approx 77^\circ\)

Figure 4.6: Trajectory of Brownian motion

This example shows how to sum multiple displacement vectors. We simply add the corresponding components (x, y, and z) separately. Notice that the total displacement is much shorter than the sum of the magnitudes of individual displacements, illustrating the difference between displacement and total path length. The final direction is given with respect to the x-axis in the xz-plane, since the y-component is zero.

title: Physics
text:
Instantaneous Velocity Vector

Calculated as the derivative of the position vector with respect to time. \[\vec{v}(t) = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{\vec{r}(t+\Delta t) - \vec{r}(t)}{\Delta t} = \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}\]
The velocity vector is always tangent to the particle’s path.




Figure 4.7: Velocity vector tangent to the path

In component form:
\(\vec{v}(t) = v_x(t)\hat{i} + v_y(t)\hat{j} + v_z(t)\hat{k}\)
Where:
\(v_x(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt}\)
\(v_y(t) = \frac{dy(t)}{dt}\)
\(v_z(t) = \frac{dz(t)}{dt}\)


Just like in 1D, instantaneous velocity is the rate of change of position. But now, it’s a vector derivative. Graphically, this means the velocity vector at any point on the path will point in the direction the particle is moving at that exact instant. We calculate each component of velocity by taking the derivative of the corresponding position component.

title: Physics
text:
Average Velocity Vector

Vector equivalent of 1D average velocity.
Calculated over a time interval from \(t_1\) to \(t_2\): \[\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{\vec{r}(t_2) - \vec{r}(t_1)}{t_2 - t_1}\]
This is simply the total displacement divided by the total time taken.


Average velocity is straightforward: find the total displacement (final position minus initial position) and divide it by the total time elapsed. It gives you the average rate and direction of change in position over the interval.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Calculating the Velocity Vector (1/2)
Position function of a particle: \(\vec{r}(t) = 2.0t^2\hat{i} + (2.0 + 3.0t)\hat{j} + 5.0t\hat{k} \text{ m}\)

What is the instantaneous velocity and speed at \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\)?
What is the average velocity between \(1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(3.0 \text{ s}\)?


Let’s break this down into two parts: instantaneous velocity and average velocity. For instantaneous, we’ll need to take a derivative. For average, we’ll use the displacement formula.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Calculating the Velocity Vector (2/2)
Solution:

Instantaneous velocity and speed at \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\)


Take the derivative of \(\vec{r}(t)\) with respect to time to get \(\vec{v}(t)\):
\(\vec{v}(t) = \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}(2.0t^2)\hat{i} + \frac{d}{dt}(2.0 + 3.0t)\hat{j} + \frac{d}{dt}(5.0t)\hat{k}\)
\(\vec{v}(t) = 4.0t\hat{i} + 3.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k} \text{ m/s}\)
Substitute \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\):
\(\vec{v}(2.0 \text{ s}) = 4.0(2.0)\hat{i} + 3.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k}\)
\(\vec{v}(2.0 \text{ s}) = 8.0\hat{i} + 3.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k} \text{ m/s}\)
Speed is the magnitude of velocity:
\(|\vec{v}(2.0 \text{ s})| = \sqrt{(8.0)^2 + (3.0)^2 + (5.0)^2} = \sqrt{64 + 9 + 25} = \sqrt{98} \approx 9.9 \text{ m/s}\)


Average velocity between \(1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(3.0 \text{ s}\)


Calculate \(\vec{r}(1.0 \text{ s})\) and \(\vec{r}(3.0 \text{ s})\): \(\vec{r}(1.0 \text{ s}) = 2.0(1.0)^2\hat{i} + (2.0 + 3.0(1.0))\hat{j} + 5.0(1.0)\hat{k} = 2.0\hat{i} + 5.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k} \text{ m}\)
\(\vec{r}(3.0 \text{ s}) = 2.0(3.0)^2\hat{i} + (2.0 + 3.0(3.0))\hat{j} + 5.0(3.0)\hat{k} = 18.0\hat{i} + 11.0\hat{j} + 15.0\hat{k} \text{ m}\)
Calculate average velocity:
\(\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{\vec{r}(3.0 \text{ s}) - \vec{r}(1.0 \text{ s})}{3.0 \text{ s} - 1.0 \text{ s}}\)
\(\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{(18.0\hat{i} + 11.0\hat{j} + 15.0\hat{k}) - (2.0\hat{i} + 5.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k})}{2.0 \text{ s}}\)
\(\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{16.0\hat{i} + 6.0\hat{j} + 10.0\hat{k}}{2.0 \text{ s}} = 8.0\hat{i} + 3.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k} \text{ m/s}\)







Note


In this specific case, the average velocity equals the instantaneous velocity at \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\) because the velocity function is linear. This is generally not true.




For part (a), we differentiate each component of the position vector with respect to time to get the velocity vector. Then, we plug in \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\). The speed is simply the magnitude of this velocity vector. For part (b), we first find the position vectors at \(t=1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(t=3.0 \text{ s}\). Then we apply the average velocity formula, which is the change in position (displacement) divided by the change in time. It’s interesting to note that in this particular problem, the average velocity matches the instantaneous velocity at the midpoint of the time interval. This happens because the acceleration is constant, meaning the velocity changes linearly with time.

title: Physics
text:
Independence of Perpendicular Motions

Motion along one coordinate axis (e.g., x) does not affect motion along perpendicular axes (y, z).
Components of position and velocity equations are separate functions of time.
This allows us to analyze complex 2D/3D motion by breaking it down into independent 1D motions.


This is a fundamental concept in kinematics. It means we can solve for the x-motion, y-motion, and z-motion independently using our 1D kinematic equations, and then combine the results as vectors.

title: Physics
text:
Illustrating Independence of Motion


Example:

A woman walks from A to B in a city with square blocks.
Her eastward movement is independent of her northward movement.
Total displacement is the vector sum.


Stroboscopic Example:

One ball dropped from rest.
Another thrown horizontally from the same height.
Vertical positions are identical at all times.
Horizontal motion is constant for the thrown ball.



Figure 4.8: Two balls illustrating independent motion

The city block example is intuitive: moving east doesn’t stop you from moving north. The stroboscopic photo is a classic demonstration. Despite the horizontal motion of one ball, both balls fall vertically at the same rate. This visually proves that horizontal and vertical motions are independent, assuming negligible air resistance. This principle is crucial for understanding projectile motion.

title: Physics
text:
Key Takeaways

Position Vector \(\vec{r}(t)\): Describes a particle’s location from the origin in 2D/3D space, changing with time.
Displacement Vector \(\Delta\vec{r}\): The change in position, \(\vec{r}(t_2) - \vec{r}(t_1)\), representing the shortest path between two points.
Instantaneous Velocity Vector \(\vec{v}(t)\): The derivative of the position vector with respect to time, \(\frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}\), always tangent to the path.
Average Velocity Vector \(\vec{v}_{avg}\): Total displacement divided by the time interval, \(\frac{\Delta\vec{r}}{\Delta t}\).
Independence of Motion: Perpendicular components of motion can be analyzed separately, simplifying complex problems (e.g., projectile motion).


These are the most important points to remember from today’s discussion. Understanding these concepts is fundamental to studying more complex motion in physics.

These equations are the mathematical tools we use to describe and analyze displacement and velocity in two and three dimensions. Make sure you understand what each symbol represents and when to use each equation.

title: Physics
text:
Key Terms







Term
Definition




Position Vector
A vector that points from the origin of a coordinate system to the location of a particle at a specific time.


Displacement Vector
The vector representing the change in position of a particle, from an initial point to a final point, independent of the path taken.


Instantaneous Velocity
The velocity of a particle at a specific instant in time, given by the derivative of the position vector with respect to time.


Average Velocity
The total displacement of a particle divided by the total time taken for that displacement.


Independence of Motion
The principle that motion along perpendicular axes of a coordinate system can be analyzed separately.




Understanding these terms is crucial for a strong foundation in kinematics. They form the vocabulary we use to describe motion.

title: Physics
text:
Introduction to Free Fall
Free fall is the motion of an object solely under the influence of gravity.

Occurs near planetary surfaces where gravity is significant.
Assumes motion is one-dimensional (straight up or down).
Applies to objects falling downward and objects thrown upward.







Note


When an object is in “free fall,” it means that the only force acting on it is gravity. Air resistance and friction are assumed to be negligible.

title: Physics
text:
Gravity: A Remarkable Fact
Galileo Galilei proved that, neglecting air resistance:

All objects fall with the same constant acceleration.
This acceleration is independent of their mass.


Figure 3.26: Hammer and feather falling in air vs. vacuum. The Moon demo shows they fall at the same rate without air.

In a vacuum, a feather and a bowling ball dropped from the same height will hit the ground simultaneously. This is because gravity accelerates all masses equally. Air resistance is what makes lighter objects fall slower in everyday situations.

title: Physics
text:
Acceleration Due to Gravity (\(g\))
For objects in free fall near Earth’s surface, the acceleration is constant.

It’s called acceleration due to gravity.
Its magnitude is denoted by \(g\).
Average value: \(g = 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2\) (or \(32.2 \, \text{ft/s}^2\)).
For most problems, we round to \(g = 9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\).

Direction of \(g\):

Always directed downward (towards the center of Earth).
The sign of \(g\) in equations depends on your chosen coordinate system.

If upward is positive, then \(a = -g = -9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\).
If downward is positive, then \(a = +g = +9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\).

title: Physics
text:
One-Dimensional Motion Involving Gravity
We use the kinematic equations, replacing \(x\) with \(y\) for vertical motion, and \(a\) with \(-g\) (if upward is positive).
Assumptions for free fall:

Straight up-and-down motion.
No air resistance or friction.
Object is in free fall once released or thrown.

Key points:

If dropped, initial velocity \(v_0 = 0\).
If thrown, \(v_0\) is the speed at release.
Motion ends when object contacts ground or another object.

title: Physics
section: Kinematic Equations for Free Fall (Upward Positive)
text:
Kinematic Equations for Free Fall (Upward Positive)
When we define the upward direction as positive, then acceleration \(a = -g\). The kinematic equations become:

\(v = v_0 - gt\)
\(y = y_0 + v_0t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2\)
\(v^2 = v_0^2 - 2g(y - y_0)\)


These are simply the general kinematic equations with \(x\) replaced by \(y\) and \(a\) replaced by \(-g\). It’s crucial to be consistent with the chosen coordinate system throughout the problem.

title: Physics
text:
Problem-Solving Strategy for Free Fall

Define Coordinate System: Choose a positive direction (up or down).

This determines the sign of \(g\).

Draw a Sketch: Visualize the motion.
List Knowns & Unknowns: Identify all given values and what you need to find.
Select Equations: Choose the kinematic equation(s) that link knowns and unknowns.

title: Physics
section: Example: Free Fall of a Ball (Thrown Downward)
text:
Example: Free Fall of a Ball (Thrown Downward)
Problem: A ball is thrown downward from a 98-m-high building with an initial velocity of 4.9 m/s downward.

How much time until it hits the ground?
What is its velocity when it hits the ground?

Strategy:

Coordinate System: Origin at the top of the building (\(y_0 = 0\)). Positive direction upward. Therefore, \(a = -g = -9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\).
Knowns: \(y_0 = 0\), \(v_0 = -4.9 \, \text{m/s}\) (downward is negative), \(y = -98 \, \text{m}\) (ground is below origin).
Unknowns: (a) \(t\), (b) \(v_f\).


Figure 3.27: Ball thrown downward from a building.

The choice of coordinate system is critical. Here, choosing upward as positive makes the initial velocity and final position negative.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Part a)
Solution (Part a): Time to reach ground (\(t\))
Use \(y = y_0 + v_0t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2\): \[ -98.0 \, \text{m} = 0 + (-4.9 \, \text{m/s})t - \frac{1}{2}(9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2)t^2 \] \[ -98.0 = -4.9t - 4.9t^2 \] Rearrange into a quadratic equation (\(4.9t^2 + 4.9t - 98.0 = 0\)), then divide by 4.9: \[ t^2 + t - 20 = 0 \] Using the quadratic formula \(t = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\): \[ t = \frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{1^2 - 4(1)(-20)}}{2(1)} = \frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{1 + 80}}{2} = \frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{81}}{2} = \frac{-1 \pm 9}{2} \]
Two solutions: \(t = \frac{-1 + 9}{2} = 4.0 \, \text{s}\) and \(t = \frac{-1 - 9}{2} = -5.0 \, \text{s}\).
Since time cannot be negative from release, \(t = 4.0 \, \text{s}\).

The negative root corresponds to a hypothetical scenario where the ball started from the ground, was thrown upwards, passed the top of the building at 4.9 m/s downward, and continued its trajectory. In this problem’s context, only the positive time is relevant.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Part b)
Solution (Part b): Velocity at ground (\(v\))
Use \(v = v_0 - gt\): \[ v = -4.9 \, \text{m/s} - (9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2)(4.0 \, \text{s}) \] \[ v = -4.9 \, \text{m/s} - 39.2 \, \text{m/s} \] \[ v = -44.1 \, \text{m/s} \]
Significance:

The negative velocity confirms the ball is moving downward.
The velocity is not zero immediately upon hitting the ground; it changes rapidly after impact.
This problem emphasizes consistent use of the coordinate system and signs.


The problem illustrates how important it is to be clear about the object’s state during free fall versus after it interacts with a surface. Free-fall equations apply only while gravity is the sole significant force.

title: Physics
section: Example: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Thrown Upward)
text:
Example: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Thrown Upward)
Problem: A baseball is hit straight upward and caught 5.0 s later at the same location.

Initial velocity (\(v_0\))?

Maximum height (\(y_{\text{max}}\))?

Time to reach maximum height (\(t_{\text{peak}}\))?

Acceleration at the top of its path?

Velocity when caught (\(v_f\))?

Strategy:

Coordinate System: Origin at home plate (\(y_0 = 0\)). Positive direction upward. Therefore, \(a = -g = -9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\).
Knowns: \(y_0 = 0\), \(y_f = 0\) (caught at same spot), total \(t = 5.0\) s.
Key Insight: At maximum height, \(v = 0\).


Figure 3.28: Baseball hit straight up.

The symmetry of motion in free fall is a crucial concept here: time to go up equals time to come down, and speed upon return equals initial speed (but opposite direction).

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Parts a, b, c)
Solution:
(a) Initial velocity (\(v_0\)): Use \(y = y_0 + v_0t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2\): \[ 0 = 0 + v_0(5.0 \, \text{s}) - \frac{1}{2}(9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2)(5.0 \, \text{s})^2 \] \[ 0 = 5.0v_0 - (4.9)(25) \] \[ 0 = 5.0v_0 - 122.5 \] \[ v_0 = \frac{122.5}{5.0} = 24.5 \, \text{m/s} \]
(b) Maximum height (\(y_{\text{max}}\)): At max height, \(v = 0\). Use \(v^2 = v_0^2 - 2g(y - y_0)\): \[ 0 = (24.5 \, \text{m/s})^2 - 2(9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2)(y_{\text{max}} - 0) \] \[ 0 = 600.25 - 19.6y_{\text{max}} \] \[ y_{\text{max}} = \frac{600.25}{19.6} = 30.6 \, \text{m} \]
(c) Time to reach maximum height (\(t_{\text{peak}}\)): At max height, \(v = 0\). Use \(v = v_0 - gt\): \[ 0 = 24.5 \, \text{m/s} - (9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2)t_{\text{peak}} \] \[ t_{\text{peak}} = \frac{24.5}{9.8} = 2.5 \, \text{s} \] Notice \(t_{\text{peak}}\) is half the total time (5.0 s), as expected due to symmetry.

Reiterate the concept of symmetry in vertical motion under gravity: time to rise equals time to fall. Also, the speed at any given height during ascent is equal to the speed at the same height during descent (but with opposite direction).

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Parts d & e)
Solution (continued):
(d) Acceleration at the top of its path:

The acceleration due to gravity is constant throughout the entire flight.
So, even at the peak where \(v = 0\), the acceleration is \(a = -g = -9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\).







Warning


A common misconception is that acceleration is zero at the peak of the trajectory. This is incorrect; velocity is momentarily zero, but acceleration due to gravity is always acting downward.



(e) Velocity when caught (\(v_f\)):
Use \(v = v_0 - gt\) for the entire 5.0 s flight: \[ v_f = 24.5 \, \text{m/s} - (9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2)(5.0 \, \text{s}) \] \[ v_f = 24.5 \, \text{m/s} - 49.0 \, \text{m/s} \] \[ v_f = -24.5 \, \text{m/s} \]
Significance:
The final velocity is equal in magnitude but opposite in direction to the initial velocity, due to the symmetry of free fall when starting and ending at the same height.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.7
Problem: A chunk of ice breaks off a glacier and falls 30.0 m.
Assuming free fall, how long does it take to hit the water?
Which quantity increases faster, the speed of the ice chunk or its distance traveled?


Given:

\(y_0 = 30.0\) m (or \(y_0=0, y=-30.0\) m)
\(v_0 = 0\) m/s (falls from rest)
\(g = 9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\)


Formulas to use:

For time: \(y = y_0 + v_0t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2\) (if upward positive) or \(y = y_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}gt^2\) (if downward positive)
Speed increases linearly with time (\(v=gt\)).
Distance increases quadratically with time (\(y=\frac{1}{2}gt^2\)).



Guide students to choose a coordinate system (e.g., origin at initial height, positive down). \(y = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 \Rightarrow 30.0 = \frac{1}{2}(9.8)t^2 \Rightarrow t = \sqrt{60/9.8} \approx 2.47\) s. Distance increases quadratically (\(t^2\)), while speed increases linearly (\(t\)), so distance increases faster.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Rocket Booster
Problem: A rocket releases its booster at a height of 5.0 km with a velocity of 200.0 m/s (upward).

What is the maximum height the booster attains (from release point)?
What is the velocity of the booster at a height of 6.0 km (from ground)?

Strategy:

Coordinate System: Origin at the point of booster release (\(y_0 = 0\)). Positive direction upward. So, \(a = -g = -9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\).
Initial Conditions (at release): \(y_0 = 0\), \(v_0 = 200.0\) m/s. (Note: The 5.0 km is the altitude of the origin above ground.)
Key Insight for (a): At maximum height, \(v = 0\).


Figure 3.29: Rocket releasing its booster.

The problem asks for maximum height attained by the booster (from the point of release), which clarifies the \(y_0=0\) choice for the booster’s motion. Part (b) will require careful interpretation of the 6.0 km height.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Part a)
Solution (Part a): Maximum height attained by booster
Given: \(y_0 = 0\), \(v_0 = 200.0\) m/s, \(a = -g = -9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\).
At max height, \(v = 0\).
Use \(v^2 = v_0^2 - 2g(y - y_0)\): \[ 0^2 = (200.0 \, \text{m/s})^2 - 2(9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2)(y_{\text{max}} - 0) \] \[ 0 = 40000 - 19.6y_{\text{max}} \] \[ y_{\text{max}} = \frac{40000}{19.6} \approx 2040.8 \, \text{m} \]
This is the height above the release point.
Total maximum height from Earth’s surface: \(5.0 \, \text{km} + 2.04 \, \text{km} = 7.04 \, \text{km}\).

Ensure students distinguish between height relative to the origin and total height from the ground. The 2040.8 m is the additional height gained after release.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Part b)
Solution (Part b): Velocity at height of 6.0 km

The 6.0 km height is from the ground.
Our origin is at 5.0 km from the ground.
So, the booster’s position \(y\) in our coordinate system is \(6.0 \, \text{km} - 5.0 \, \text{km} = 1.0 \, \text{km} = 1000 \, \text{m}\).

Given: \(y_0 = 0\), \(v_0 = 200.0\) m/s, \(a = -g = -9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\), \(y = 1000\) m.
Use \(v^2 = v_0^2 - 2g(y - y_0)\): \[ v^2 = (200.0 \, \text{m/s})^2 - 2(9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2)(1000 \, \text{m} - 0) \] \[ v^2 = 40000 - 19600 \] \[ v^2 = 20400 \] \[ v = \pm\sqrt{20400} \approx \pm 142.8 \, \text{m/s} \]
Significance:

The positive solution (\(+142.8\) m/s) is the velocity when the booster is still moving upward at 6.0 km altitude.
The negative solution (\(-142.8\) m/s) is the velocity when the booster is moving downward at 6.0 km altitude (after reaching its peak and falling).
Both are physically meaningful.


The appearance of both positive and negative roots is common in these types of problems, and both are physically significant, representing motion in different directions at the same position. This reinforces understanding of vector directions.

title: Physics
text:
Key Takeaways

Free Fall Definition: Motion under gravity alone, neglecting air resistance.
Acceleration due to Gravity (\(g\)):

Constant: \(9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2\) (near Earth).
Direction: Always downward.
Independent of mass.

Coordinate System: Crucial for setting the sign of acceleration (\(a = \pm g\)).

If upward is positive, \(a = -g\).
If downward is positive, \(a = +g\).

Kinematic Equations: The standard constant acceleration equations apply, with \(y\) for displacement and \(\pm g\) for acceleration.
Symmetry in Vertical Motion:

Time to ascend equals time to descend (to the same height).
Speed at a given height during ascent equals speed at the same height during descent.

Acceleration at Peak: Velocity is zero, but acceleration is still \(g\) (downward).

title: Physics
text:
Introduction to Acceleration
Acceleration is a fundamental concept in physics describing how velocity changes over time.

Everyday Examples:

Car speeding up or slowing down.
Elevator starting or stopping.

Advanced Physics:

Particles in accelerators reaching high velocities.
Cosmic rays accelerated in supernovas.








Note


Understanding acceleration is crucial for analyzing motion from daily experiences to the vastness of space.

title: Physics
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this presentation, you will be able to:

Calculate average acceleration between two points in time.
Determine instantaneous acceleration from a velocity function.
Explain the vector nature of instantaneous acceleration and velocity.
Distinguish between average and instantaneous acceleration.
Find instantaneous acceleration from a velocity-versus-time graph.

title: Physics
text:
Average Acceleration
Average acceleration (\(\bar{a}\)) is the rate at which velocity changes over a specific time interval.
\[ \bar{a} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{v_f - v_0}{t_f - t_0} \]
Where:

\(\bar{a}\) is average acceleration.
\(\Delta v\) is the change in velocity.
\(\Delta t\) is the change in time.
\(v_f\) is final velocity, \(v_0\) is initial velocity.
\(t_f\) is final time, \(t_0\) is initial time.


The bar over ‘a’ specifically denotes average acceleration. It represents the overall change in velocity over a duration, not at a single moment.

title: Physics
text:
Units of Acceleration
The SI unit for acceleration is meters per second squared (m/s²).

This means “meters per second per second.”
It describes how many meters per second the velocity changes every second.







Tip


Think of m/s² as (m/s) / s. It represents the change in velocity (m/s) per unit of time (s).

title: Physics
text:
Acceleration as a Vector
Velocity is a vector (magnitude and direction), so a change in velocity can be:

A change in magnitude (speeding up or slowing down).
A change in direction.
Both.

Therefore, acceleration is also a vector quantity. It points in the same direction as the change in velocity (\(\Delta v\)).

A common misconception is that acceleration only means speeding up. However, changing direction, even at constant speed, is also acceleration. For example, a car turning a corner at a constant speed is accelerating because its velocity vector’s direction is changing.

title: Physics
text:
Deceleration: A Misleading Term
The term “deceleration” can be confusing.

It’s often used to mean “slowing down.”
However, it is not a vector and does not point in a specific direction.

In physics, we use negative acceleration when an object slows down while moving in the positive direction.

Figure 3.10: A subway train coming into a station. It is accelerating in a direction opposite to its direction of motion.

If a train is moving east (positive direction) and brakes, its acceleration is directed west (negative direction). This is negative acceleration, not “deceleration.” Using vector signs correctly avoids ambiguity.

title: Physics
text:
Direction of Motion and Acceleration
Acceleration is not always in the direction of motion.

When an object speeds up, acceleration is in the same direction as velocity.
When an object slows down, acceleration is opposite to the direction of velocity.




Figure 3.11: Object with initial velocity east, negative acceleration, comes to rest and reverses direction.

Example:

Car moving East (positive velocity).
Applies brakes (negative acceleration).
Car slows down, stops, then if force continues, moves West (negative velocity).



This graph illustrates that an object can have positive velocity and negative acceleration, meaning it is slowing down. If the negative acceleration persists, the object will eventually stop and then reverse direction, gaining speed in the negative direction.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Calculating Average Acceleration
Problem: A racehorse accelerates from rest to 15.0 m/s due west in 1.80 s. What is its average acceleration?
Strategy:

Assign Coordinate System: Let East be positive, West be negative.

\(v_0 = 0\) m/s (from rest).
\(v_f = -15.0\) m/s (negative for West).
\(\Delta t = 1.80\) s.

Calculate \(\Delta v\): \(\Delta v = v_f - v_0\).
Apply Average Acceleration Formula: \(\bar{a} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}\).


Visualizing the problem with a diagram and a clear coordinate system is always the first step. This helps prevent errors in assigning signs to vector quantities like velocity and acceleration.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution
Solution:

Knowns:

\(v_0 = 0\) m/s
\(v_f = -15.0\) m/s
\(\Delta t = 1.80\) s

Change in Velocity: \[ \Delta v = v_f - v_0 = -15.0 \, \text{m/s} - 0 \, \text{m/s} = -15.0 \, \text{m/s} \]
Average Acceleration: \[ \bar{a} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{-15.0 \, \text{m/s}}{1.80 \, \text{s}} = -8.33 \, \text{m/s}^2 \]

Significance:
The negative sign indicates the acceleration is due west.
The horse increases its velocity by 8.33 m/s due west each second.

The magnitude of the acceleration tells us how rapidly the velocity is changing, while the sign tells us the direction of that change relative to our chosen coordinate system.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.3
Problem: Protons in a linear accelerator are accelerated from rest to \(2.0 \times 10^7\) m/s in \(10^{-4}\) s.
What is the average acceleration of the protons?


Given:

\(v_0 = 0\) m/s
\(v_f = 2.0 \times 10^7\) m/s
\(\Delta t = 10^{-4}\) s


Formula: \[ \bar{a} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \]


Encourage students to calculate this on their own.
The answer should be \(2.0 \times 10^{11}\) m/s².
This emphasizes how large accelerations can be in particle physics.

title: Physics
text:
Instantaneous Acceleration
Instantaneous acceleration (\(a\)) is the acceleration at a specific instant in time.

It’s the limit of average acceleration as \(\Delta t\) approaches zero.
Mathematically, it’s the derivative of the velocity function with respect to time.

\[ a(t) = \frac{d}{dt} v(t) \]






Important


Instantaneous acceleration is to velocity what instantaneous velocity is to position.
It describes the rate of change at a particular moment.

title: Physics
text:
Instantaneous Acceleration Graphically
On a velocity-versus-time graph:

Instantaneous acceleration at time \(t_0\) is the slope of the tangent line to the curve at \(t_0\).


Figure 3.14: Instantaneous acceleration is the slope of the tangent line on a velocity-time graph.

Point out that where the tangent line is horizontal (slope is zero), the instantaneous acceleration is zero. This corresponds to a maximum or minimum velocity.

title: Physics
text:
Constant Acceleration Example
Consider a linear velocity-time graph:

Figure 3.15: (a) Linear velocity-time graph, (b) corresponding constant acceleration-time graph.

If the velocity function is a straight line, its slope is constant.
This means the acceleration is constant.
The acceleration-time graph will be a horizontal line.


In this specific example, the velocity is decreasing linearly, so the slope (acceleration) is a constant negative value.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Calculating Instantaneous Acceleration
Problem: A particle’s velocity is given by \(v(t) = (20 \, \text{m/s}^2)t - (5 \, \text{m/s}^3)t^2\).

Find the functional form of acceleration \(a(t)\).
Find instantaneous velocity at \(t = 1, 2, 3, 5\) s.
Find instantaneous acceleration at \(t = 1, 2, 3, 5\) s.
Interpret the results of (c) concerning the directions of acceleration and velocity.


This example requires taking a derivative and then plugging in values. It directly connects the mathematical definition of instantaneous acceleration to numerical results and physical interpretation.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Parts 1 & 2)
Solution:

Functional form of acceleration: Take the derivative of \(v(t)\): \[ a(t) = \frac{dv(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} [(20 \, \text{m/s}^2)t - (5 \, \text{m/s}^3)t^2] \] \[ a(t) = (20 \, \text{m/s}^2) - (10 \, \text{m/s}^3)t \]
Instantaneous velocity at specified times:

\(v(1 \, \text{s}) = (20)(1) - (5)(1)^2 = 15 \, \text{m/s}\)
\(v(2 \, \text{s}) = (20)(2) - (5)(2)^2 = 40 - 20 = 20 \, \text{m/s}\)
\(v(3 \, \text{s}) = (20)(3) - (5)(3)^2 = 60 - 45 = 15 \, \text{m/s}\)
\(v(5 \, \text{s}) = (20)(5) - (5)(5)^2 = 100 - 125 = -25 \, \text{m/s}\)



Review the rules of differentiation for polynomials. \(d/dt (ct^n) = cnt^{n-1}\). Stress the units in each term to ensure consistency.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Parts 3 & 4)
Solution (continued):

Instantaneous acceleration at specified times:

\(a(1 \, \text{s}) = 20 - (10)(1) = 10 \, \text{m/s}^2\)
\(a(2 \, \text{s}) = 20 - (10)(2) = 0 \, \text{m/s}^2\)
\(a(3 \, \text{s}) = 20 - (10)(3) = -10 \, \text{m/s}^2\)
\(a(5 \, \text{s}) = 20 - (10)(5) = -30 \, \text{m/s}^2\)

Interpretation:

\(t=1\) s: \(v > 0\), \(a > 0\). Particle is speeding up in the positive direction.
\(t=2\) s: \(v = 20\) m/s (maximum), \(a = 0\). Velocity is momentarily not changing.
\(t=3\) s: \(v > 0\), \(a < 0\). Particle is slowing down while still moving in the positive direction.
\(t=5\) s: \(v < 0\), \(a < 0\). Particle has reversed direction and is speeding up in the negative direction.



This interpretation is key to understanding the relationship between velocity and acceleration vectors. When velocity and acceleration have the same sign, the object is speeding up. When they have opposite signs, it’s slowing down. When acceleration is zero, velocity is at a maximum or minimum.

title: Physics
text:
Graphical Analysis of Example 3.6

Figure 3.16: (a) Velocity-time graph. (b) Acceleration-time graph.

(a) Velocity vs. Time: Shows velocity increases, reaches a maximum at \(t=2\)s, then decreases and becomes negative.
(b) Acceleration vs. Time: Shows acceleration is positive, crosses zero at \(t=2\)s, and then becomes increasingly negative.
The maximum velocity occurs when acceleration is zero.


Connecting the numerical results to the graphs reinforces the concepts. The slope of the velocity graph (a) directly corresponds to the values on the acceleration graph (b).

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.4
Problem: An airplane lands on a runway traveling east. Describe its acceleration.


Scenario:

Airplane moves east (e.g., positive direction).
It is landing, so it must be slowing down.


Description:

Since the airplane is slowing down, its acceleration vector must be opposite to its velocity vector.
Therefore, the airplane’s acceleration is directed west (negative direction).



This simple scenario helps solidify the concept that acceleration is opposite to motion when slowing down.

Average vs. Instantaneous Acceleration (Graphical Comparison)

Figure 3.17: (a) Nearly constant acceleration. (b) Highly variable acceleration.

Key Takeaways

text:
Key Terms







Term
Definition

title: Physics
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this section, you will be able to:

Define position, displacement, and distance traveled.
Calculate the total displacement given the position as a function of time.
Determine the total distance traveled.
Calculate the average velocity given the displacement and elapsed time.


Welcome to our first topic in kinematics: Position, Displacement, and Average Velocity. Understanding these fundamental concepts is crucial for describing any kind of motion. We’ll define each term, learn how to calculate them, and see how they relate to each other.

title: Physics
text:
Describing Motion: Position
To describe motion, we first need to define position (x).

Position tells us where an object is at a particular time.
It’s always specified relative to a convenient frame of reference.

Frame of Reference

An arbitrary set of axes from which position and motion are described.
Often Earth is used as a reference frame (e.g., buildings, landmarks).
Can also be a moving reference frame (e.g., inside an airplane).


Think of position as an address. You can’t just say “I’m here,” you need to say “I’m here relative to something.” For example, 5 meters to the right of the whiteboard. The choice of reference frame is important and can simplify the description of motion. For one-dimensional motion, we typically use the variable ‘x’ for horizontal motion and ‘y’ for vertical motion.

title: Physics
text:
Displacement
Displacement (\(\Delta x\)) is the change in an object’s position.

It’s a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude and direction.
Can be positive or negative, depending on the chosen positive direction.

\[ \Delta x = x_f - x_0 \]

\(\Delta x\): displacement
\(x_f\): final position
\(x_0\): initial position







Note


The SI unit for displacement is meters (m).




Displacement is not just how far an object has moved, but also in what direction. If you walk 5 meters forward and then 3 meters backward, your displacement is 2 meters forward, not 8 meters. The Greek letter delta, \(\Delta\), always means “change in” a quantity, calculated as the final value minus the initial value.

title: Physics
text:
Total Displacement
An object can have a series of displacements.

Total displacement (\(\Delta x_{Total}\)) is the sum of individual displacements.

\[ \Delta x_{Total} = \sum \Delta x_i \]

\(\Delta x_i\): individual displacements.

Example:

A professor moves 2 m to the right (\(\Delta x_1 = +2\) m).
Then moves 4 m to the left (\(\Delta x_2 = -4\) m).

Total displacement: \(\Delta x_{Total} = \Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2 = 2 \, \text{m} + (-4 \, \text{m}) = -2 \, \text{m}\)

Figure 3.3: Displacement of a professor.

The total displacement tells us the net change in position from the very beginning to the very end of the motion, regardless of the path taken in between. It only depends on the initial and final positions. The magnitude of displacement is always positive, representing the size of the displacement.

title: Physics
text:
Distance Traveled
Distance traveled (\(x_{Total}\)) is different from displacement.

It is the total length of the path traveled between two positions.
It is a scalar quantity, always positive.

\[ x_{Total} = \sum |\Delta x_i| \]

\(|\Delta x_i|\): magnitude of individual displacements.



Example (continued):

Professor moves 2 m to the right (\(\Delta x_1 = +2\) m).
Then moves 4 m to the left (\(\Delta x_2 = -4\) m).

Total distance traveled: \(x_{Total} = |\Delta x_1| + |\Delta x_2| = |+2 \, \text{m}| + |-4 \, \text{m}| = 2 \, \text{m} + 4 \, \text{m} = 6 \, \text{m}\)







Important


Displacement focuses on the net change, while distance traveled accounts for every step of the journey.





So, for the professor, the total displacement was -2 meters, meaning she ended up 2 meters to the left of her starting point. But the total distance she walked was 6 meters. This distinction is crucial in physics.

title: Physics
text:
Average Velocity
Average velocity (\(\bar{v}\)) is the rate at which position changes over time.

It’s a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude and direction.
Can be positive or negative, depending on the displacement.

\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\text{Displacement between two points}}{\text{Time needed to make the displacement}} \] \[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_2 - x_1}{t_2 - t_1} \]

\(\Delta t\): elapsed time (\(t_2 - t_1\)).







Note


The SI unit for average velocity is meters per second (m/s).




Average velocity tells us the overall speed and direction of motion over a period of time. It doesn’t tell us what happened at every instant, just the average rate of change. For example, if you travel 100 km in 2 hours, your average velocity is 50 km/h, even if you stopped for a coffee break or sped up at times.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Delivering Flyers - Part 1
Jill delivers flyers. Let’s analyze her trip.

Figure 3.4: Timeline of Jill’s movements.


Trip Details:

Leg 1: 0.5 km East (9 min).
Leg 2: 0.5 km West (9 min) - Back to house.
Leg 3: 1.0 km East (15 min) - Continues where she left off.
Leg 4: 1.75 km West (25 min) - Stops to rest.


Strategy:

Define East as positive direction.
Create a table of positions and times.
Calculate individual displacements.



This example allows us to apply all the concepts we just discussed. It’s a multi-leg journey, which will help illustrate the difference between total displacement and total distance. Setting up a table is a good strategy to organize the data.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Delivering Flyers - Part 2
Table of Jill’s Movements (East = positive):








Time \(t_i\) (min)
Position \(x_i\) (km)
Displacement \(\Delta x_i\) (km)




\(t_0 = 0\)
\(x_0 = 0\)
\(\Delta x_0 = 0\)


\(t_1 = 9\)
\(x_1 = 0.5\)
\(\Delta x_1 = x_1 - x_0 = 0.5\)


\(t_2 = 18\)
\(x_2 = 0\)
\(\Delta x_2 = x_2 - x_1 = -0.5\)


\(t_3 = 33\)
\(x_3 = 1.0\)
\(\Delta x_3 = x_3 - x_2 = 1.0\)


\(t_4 = 58\)
\(x_4 = -0.75\)
\(\Delta x_4 = x_4 - x_3 = -1.75\)



1. Total Displacement:

Sum of individual displacements: \(\sum \Delta x_i = 0.5 - 0.5 + 1.0 - 1.75 \, \text{km} = -0.75 \, \text{km}\) (Jill is 0.75 km West of her home)

2. Magnitude of Final Displacement:

\(|-0.75 \, \text{km}| = 0.75 \, \text{km}\)


The table helps us track Jill’s position at different times and calculate the displacement for each leg of her journey. Notice how the displacement for leg 2 is negative because she moved west, back towards her home. For total displacement, we simply add these signed values. The magnitude is just the positive value.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Delivering Flyers - Part 3
3. Average Velocity:

Average velocity = \(\frac{\text{Total displacement}}{\text{Elapsed time}}\)
\(\bar{v} = \frac{-0.75 \, \text{km}}{58 \, \text{min}} \approx -0.013 \, \text{km/min}\) (This means an average of 0.013 km/min West).

4. Total Distance Traveled:

Sum of magnitudes of individual displacements: \(x_{Total} = \sum |\Delta x_i| = |0.5| + |-0.5| + |1.0| + |-1.75| \, \text{km} = 0.5 + 0.5 + 1.0 + 1.75 \, \text{km} = 3.75 \, \text{km}\)


The average velocity is directly linked to the total displacement. If Jill had ended up back at her house, her total displacement would be zero, and thus her average velocity would also be zero, regardless of how much distance she covered. In contrast, the total distance traveled sums up all the paths she took, regardless of direction.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Delivering Flyers - Part 4
5. Graph of Position vs. Time:

Figure 3.5: Jill’s position versus time.






Tip


The slope of a position-time graph represents velocity. For average velocity, it’s the slope of the line connecting the initial and final points.




A position-time graph is a powerful tool for visualizing motion. We can see how Jill’s position changes over time. Notice the negative slope when she moves west and the positive slope when she moves east. The average velocity for the entire trip corresponds to the slope of the dashed line connecting the start (0,0) to the end (58 min, -0.75 km).

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding
A cyclist rides 3 km west and then turns around and rides 2 km east.

Let’s assume East is the positive direction.

What is their displacement?
What is the distance traveled?
What is the magnitude of their displacement?


Take a moment to work through this problem using the definitions and equations we’ve covered. Remember to consider direction for displacement, and the absolute value for distance.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding - Solution
Let’s assume East is the positive direction.

Leg 1: 3 km west \(\implies \Delta x_1 = -3 \, \text{km}\)
Leg 2: 2 km east \(\implies \Delta x_2 = +2 \, \text{km}\)

(a) What is their displacement?
\(\Delta x_{Total} = \Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2 = -3 \, \text{km} + 2 \, \text{km} = -1 \, \text{km}\) (The cyclist is 1 km West of their starting point).
(b) What is the distance traveled?
\(x_{Total} = |\Delta x_1| + |\Delta x_2| = |-3 \, \text{km}| + |+2 \, \text{km}| = 3 \, \text{km} + 2 \, \text{km} = 5 \, \text{km}\)
(c) What is the magnitude of their displacement?
\(|\Delta x_{Total}| = |-1 \, \text{km}| = 1 \, \text{km}\)

Notice how displacement is negative because the final position is to the west of the start, while distance traveled is a larger, positive value because it sums the total path length. The magnitude of displacement is simply the positive value of the total displacement.

title: Physics
text:
Key Takeaways

Position (x): Where an object is relative to a reference frame.
Displacement (\(\Delta x\)): The change in position, a vector quantity (\(\Delta x = x_f - x_0\)).
Total Displacement (\(\Delta x_{Total}\)): The sum of individual displacements (\(\sum \Delta x_i\)).
Distance Traveled (\(x_{Total}\)): The total length of the path covered, a scalar quantity (\(\sum |\Delta x_i|\)).
Average Velocity (\(\bar{v}\)): The total displacement divided by the elapsed time (\(\bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}\)), a vector quantity.


These five points are the core concepts from this section. Ensure you can distinguish between displacement and distance, and understand why velocity is a vector while distance is a scalar.

Learning Objectives
By the end of this section, you will be able to:

Explain the difference between average velocity and instantaneous velocity.
Describe the difference between velocity and speed.
Calculate the instantaneous velocity given the mathematical equation for the position.
Calculate the speed given the instantaneous velocity.


In the previous section, we learned about average velocity, which gives us an overall picture of motion over a time interval. Now, we’re going to dive into instantaneous velocity, which tells us how fast an object is moving at a single point in time. This requires an introduction to calculus, specifically derivatives. We’ll also clarify the important distinction between velocity and speed.

title: Physics
text:
Instantaneous Velocity
Instantaneous velocity (often just called velocity) is how fast an object is moving at any single point along its path.

It is the limit of the average velocity as the elapsed time approaches zero.
Mathematically, it’s the derivative of position with respect to time.

\[ v(t) = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{x(t + \Delta t) - x(t)}{\Delta t} = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} \]

Like average velocity, it’s a vector quantity (magnitude and direction).
The instantaneous velocity at time \(t_0\) is the slope of the tangent line to the position-time graph at \(t_0\).


Imagine a speedometer in a car. That’s instantaneous speed. Instantaneous velocity adds the direction. If your position function is \(x(t)\), then taking its derivative gives you the instantaneous velocity function \(v(t)\). This is a fundamental concept in calculus-based physics. The idea of the limit means we’re looking at smaller and smaller time intervals until it’s practically an instant.

title: Physics
text:
Instantaneous Velocity on a Graph

Figure 3.6: In a graph of position versus time, the instantaneous velocity is the slope of the tangent line at a given point.

At \(t_0\), the slope is zero, so \(v(t_0) = 0\).
At other times like \(t_1, t_2\), the slope is positive or negative, indicating non-zero velocity.







Tip


The zeros of the velocity function (\(v(t)=0\)) correspond to the maximum or minimum points of the position function \(x(t)\). This is where the object momentarily stops and potentially reverses direction.




This graph clearly illustrates the concept. As the time interval \(\Delta t\) gets smaller and smaller, the average velocity (slope of the secant line) approaches the instantaneous velocity (slope of the tangent line). When the position graph reaches a peak or a valley, its slope is momentarily zero, meaning the object has zero instantaneous velocity at that exact moment.

title: Physics
section: Example: Velocity from a Position-Time Graph
text:
Example: Velocity from a Position-Time Graph
Given the position-versus-time graph, find the velocity-versus-time graph.

Figure 3.7: Object moving away, stopping, and reversing direction.
Strategy:

The graph consists of three straight line segments.
For straight lines, the average velocity equals the instantaneous velocity.
Calculate the slope (\(\Delta x / \Delta t\)) for each segment.


When the position-time graph is made of straight lines, the velocity is constant during each segment. This simplifies finding the instantaneous velocity, as it’s simply the slope of that line segment.

title: Physics
section: Example: Velocity from a Position-Time Graph (Solution)
text:
Example: Velocity from a Position-Time Graph (Solution)
Calculations:

Interval 1 (0 s to 0.5 s): \(v = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.5 \, \text{m} - 0.0 \, \text{m}}{0.5 \, \text{s} - 0.0 \, \text{s}} = 1.0 \, \text{m/s}\)
Interval 2 (0.5 s to 1.0 s): \(v = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.5 \, \text{m} - 0.5 \, \text{m}}{1.0 \, \text{s} - 0.5 \, \text{s}} = 0.0 \, \text{m/s}\)
Interval 3 (1.0 s to 2.0 s): \(v = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.0 \, \text{m} - 0.5 \, \text{m}}{2.0 \, \text{s} - 1.0 \, \text{s}} = -0.5 \, \text{m/s}\)

Velocity-Time Graph:

Figure 3.8: Velocity versus time.

The calculated velocities for each interval directly translate into the velocity-time graph. A positive slope on the position graph means positive velocity, a zero slope means zero velocity, and a negative slope means negative velocity. This demonstrates the direct relationship between the slope of a position-time graph and velocity.

title: Physics
text:
Speed
In physics, speed and velocity are distinct concepts.

Speed is a scalar quantity: it only has magnitude.
Velocity is a vector quantity: it has both magnitude and direction.



Average Speed (\(\bar{s}\))

Total distance traveled divided by elapsed time. \[ \bar{s} = \frac{\text{Total distance}}{\text{Elapsed time}} \]
Not necessarily the magnitude of average velocity. (e.g., if you start and end at the same place, \(\bar{v}=0\) but \(\bar{s} \neq 0\)).


Instantaneous Speed

The magnitude of the instantaneous velocity. \[ \text{Instantaneous speed} = |v(t)| \]
Always positive or zero.



Think of it this way: your car’s speedometer shows speed. If you’re driving at 60 mph, that’s your speed. Your velocity might be 60 mph North, or 60 mph South. If you drive in a circle and end up where you started, your average velocity is zero (because displacement is zero), but your average speed is definitely not zero because you covered a distance.

title: Physics
text:
Calculating Instantaneous Velocity (using Calculus)
To calculate instantaneous velocity from a position function \(x(t)\), we use differentiation.

If \(x(t)\) is a polynomial where each term has the form \(A t^n\):

\[ \frac{d(A t^n)}{dt} = A n t^{n-1} \]

If \(x(t)\) has multiple terms added together, differentiate each term and sum them up.







Note


This is the power rule of differentiation, a fundamental tool in calculus for finding rates of change.




This rule is extremely useful in physics. For example, if your position is given by \(x(t) = 5t^2 + 3t - 2\), then your velocity function would be \(v(t) = 10t + 3\). We’ll see how this works in an example.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Instantaneous vs. Average Velocity
The position of a particle is given by \(x(t) = (3.0 \, \text{m/s})t + (0.5 \, \text{m/s}^3)t^3\).
1. Find the instantaneous velocity at \(t = 2.0\) s.

First, find the general velocity function by differentiating \(x(t)\):
\(v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} [(3.0 \, \text{m/s})t + (0.5 \, \text{m/s}^3)t^3]\)
\(v(t) = (3.0 \, \text{m/s}) + (0.5 \times 3 \, \text{m/s}^3)t^{3-1}\)
\(v(t) = (3.0 \, \text{m/s}) + (1.5 \, \text{m/s}^3)t^2\)
Now, substitute \(t = 2.0\) s into \(v(t)\):
\(v(2.0 \, \text{s}) = (3.0 \, \text{m/s}) + (1.5 \, \text{m/s}^3)(2.0 \, \text{s})^2\)
\(v(2.0 \, \text{s}) = 3.0 \, \text{m/s} + (1.5 \, \text{m/s}^3)(4.0 \, \text{s}^2)\)
\(v(2.0 \, \text{s}) = 3.0 \, \text{m/s} + 6.0 \, \text{m/s} = 9.0 \, \text{m/s}\)


Here, we apply the power rule. For the first term, \(t\) is \(t^1\), so \(A=3.0\), \(n=1\), giving \(3.0 \times 1 \times t^0 = 3.0\). For the second term, \(A=0.5\), \(n=3\), giving \(0.5 \times 3 \times t^2 = 1.5t^2\).

title: Physics
text:
Example: Instantaneous vs. Average Velocity (continued)
The position of a particle is given by \(x(t) = (3.0 \, \text{m/s})t + (0.5 \, \text{m/s}^3)t^3\).
2. Calculate the average velocity between 1.0 s and 3.0 s.

First, find the positions at \(t = 1.0\) s and \(t = 3.0\) s:
\(x(1.0 \, \text{s}) = (3.0 \, \text{m/s})(1.0 \, \text{s}) + (0.5 \, \text{m/s}^3)(1.0 \, \text{s})^3 = 3.0 \, \text{m} + 0.5 \, \text{m} = 3.5 \, \text{m}\)
\(x(3.0 \, \text{s}) = (3.0 \, \text{m/s})(3.0 \, \text{s}) + (0.5 \, \text{m/s}^3)(3.0 \, \text{s})^3 = 9.0 \, \text{m} + (0.5 \, \text{m/s}^3)(27 \, \text{s}^3) = 9.0 \, \text{m} + 13.5 \, \text{m} = 22.5 \, \text{m}\)
Now, calculate average velocity:
\(\bar{v} = \frac{x(3.0 \, \text{s}) - x(1.0 \, \text{s})}{3.0 \, \text{s} - 1.0 \, \text{s}} = \frac{22.5 \, \text{m} - 3.5 \, \text{m}}{2.0 \, \text{s}} = \frac{19.0 \, \text{m}}{2.0 \, \text{s}} = 9.5 \, \text{m/s}\)







Important


Notice that the instantaneous velocity at \(t=2.0\) s (\(9.0 \, \text{m/s}\)) is close to, but not exactly equal to, the average velocity over the interval from \(1.0\) s to \(3.0\) s (\(9.5 \, \text{m/s}\)). As the interval shrinks around \(t=2.0\) s, the average velocity would approach the instantaneous velocity.




This highlights the difference between instantaneous and average velocity. The average velocity calculation is much simpler, as it doesn’t require calculus, but it only provides a general idea of motion over an interval.

title: Physics
text:
Position, Velocity, and Speed Graphs
Consider \(x(t) = (3.0 \, \text{m/s})t - (3 \, \text{m/s}^2)t^2\).

Instantaneous Velocity \(v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = (3.0 \, \text{m/s}) - (6.0 \, \text{m/s}^2)t\)

\(v(0.25 \, \text{s}) = 3.0 - 6.0(0.25) = 1.50 \, \text{m/s}\)
\(v(0.50 \, \text{s}) = 3.0 - 6.0(0.50) = 0 \, \text{m/s}\)
\(v(1.0 \, \text{s}) = 3.0 - 6.0(1.0) = -3.0 \, \text{m/s}\)

Speed = \(|v(t)|\)

Speed at \(0.25 \, \text{s} = |1.50 \, \text{m/s}| = 1.50 \, \text{m/s}\)
Speed at \(0.50 \, \text{s} = |0 \, \text{m/s}| = 0 \, \text{m/s}\)
Speed at \(1.0 \, \text{s} = |-3.0 \, \text{m/s}| = 3.0 \, \text{m/s}\)



Here, the position function is a parabola opening downwards. This means the object will move in one direction, momentarily stop at the peak of the parabola, and then reverse direction.

title: Physics
text:
Visualizing Position, Velocity, and Speed

Figure 3.9: (a) Position, (b) Velocity, and (c) Speed versus time.

(a) Position: Parabolic path, peaks at \(t=0.5\) s, then decreases.
(b) Velocity: Linear decrease, crosses zero at \(t=0.5\) s. Positive then negative.
(c) Speed: Always positive or zero, “V” shape. Magnitude of velocity.


These graphs clearly show the relationships. The slope of the position graph gives the velocity graph. The absolute value of the velocity graph gives the speed graph. At 0.5 seconds, the object’s velocity is zero, meaning it momentarily stops before reversing direction. Its speed also drops to zero at this point.

text:
Check Your Understanding
The position of an object as a function of time is \(x(t) = (-3 \, \text{m/s}^2)t^2\).

What is the velocity of the object as a function of time?
Is the velocity ever positive?
What are the velocity and speed at \(t = 1.0\) s?


Apply the differentiation rule you’ve learned for part (a). For part (b), consider the sign of your velocity function. For part (c), plug in the time value and then take the absolute value for speed.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding - Solution
The position of an object as a function of time is \(x(t) = (-3 \, \text{m/s}^2)t^2\).
(a) What is the velocity of the object as a function of time?
\(v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} [(-3 \, \text{m/s}^2)t^2]\)
\(v(t) = (-3 \, \text{m/s}^2)(2)t^{2-1} = (-6 \, \text{m/s}^2)t\)
(b) Is the velocity ever positive?
No. Since \(t \ge 0\) (time cannot be negative) and the coefficient is negative, \(v(t) = -6t\) will always be zero or negative.
(c) What are the velocity and speed at \(t = 1.0\) s?

Velocity:
\(v(1.0 \, \text{s}) = (-6 \, \text{m/s}^2)(1.0 \, \text{s}) = -6.0 \, \text{m/s}\)
Speed:
\(\text{Speed} = |v(1.0 \, \text{s})| = |-6.0 \, \text{m/s}| = 6.0 \, \text{m/s}\)


This example shows an object that starts at the origin and constantly moves in the negative direction, with increasing speed. Its velocity is always negative (or zero at t=0), but its speed is always positive (or zero at t=0).

title: Physics
text:
Key Takeaways

Instantaneous Velocity (\(v(t)\)): The velocity at a specific instant; it’s the derivative of the position function \(x(t)\) with respect to time (\(v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt}\)).
Slope of Position-Time Graph: The instantaneous velocity at any point is the slope of the tangent line to the \(x(t)\) graph at that point.
Speed vs. Velocity:

Velocity is a vector (magnitude and direction).
Speed is a scalar (magnitude only).

Instantaneous Speed: The magnitude of the instantaneous velocity (\(|v(t)|\)). It is always positive or zero.
Average Speed (\(\bar{s}\)): Total distance traveled divided by elapsed time. It is generally not equal to the magnitude of average velocity.


These are the most important distinctions and concepts from this section. Understanding the relationship between position, velocity, and speed, both mathematically and graphically, is key.

title: Physics
text:
Introduction to Constant Acceleration
In this section, we develop powerful equations to describe motion when acceleration is constant.

Relates displacement, velocity, acceleration, and time.
Essential for analyzing many real-world scenarios.

We will cover:

Simplified notation for kinematic variables.
Derivation of key kinematic equations.
Solving single-body motion problems.
Solving two-body pursuit problems.







Note


The assumption of constant acceleration is crucial as it simplifies calculations and allows us to avoid complex calculus for instantaneous values.

title: Physics
text:
Simplified Notation
To simplify our kinematic equations, we make some notational conventions:

Initial time (\(t_0\)) = 0: As if starting a stopwatch.

Elapsed time \(\Delta t = t_f - t_0\) becomes \(\Delta t = t\).

Subscript ‘0’ for initial values:

Initial position: \(x_0\)
Initial velocity: \(v_0\)

No subscript for final values:

Final time: \(t\)
Final position: \(x\)
Final velocity: \(v\)


This simplifies expressions:

Displacement: \(\Delta x = x - x_0\)
Change in velocity: \(\Delta v = v - v_0\)

title: Physics
text:
The Constant Acceleration Assumption
Our most important assumption: acceleration is constant.

This means \(\bar{a} = a = \text{constant}\).
We can use the symbol ‘\(a\)’ for acceleration at all times.







Tip


Why is this assumption so useful?
It means instantaneous acceleration is always equal to average acceleration, greatly simplifying problem-solving.



Justification:

Many real-world situations have constant acceleration (e.g., free fall).
For variable acceleration, motion can be broken into segments, each with approximate constant acceleration.

title: Physics
section: Kinematic Equation 1: Displacement from Average Velocity
text:
Kinematic Equation 1: Displacement from Average Velocity
We start with the definition of average velocity:
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} \]
Using simplified notation (\(\Delta x = x - x_0\), \(\Delta t = t\)):
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{x - x_0}{t} \]
Solving for \(x\):
\[ x = x_0 + \bar{v}t \]

This equation is fundamental, directly linking position, initial position, average velocity, and time.

title: Physics
text:
Average Velocity with Constant Acceleration
When acceleration is constant, the average velocity (\(\bar{v}\)) is simply the average of the initial and final velocities:
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2} \]
This relationship is visually intuitive on a velocity-time graph with constant acceleration.

Figure 3.18 (a) Constant acceleration: Average velocity is the midpoint. (b) Non-constant acceleration: Average velocity is not simply \(\frac{v_0+v}{2}\).

The area under the curve of a velocity-time graph represents displacement. For constant acceleration, this area is a trapezoid. The average height of the trapezoid is \((v_0+v)/2\). For non-constant acceleration, the shape is more complex, and a simple average does not apply.

title: Physics
section: Kinematic Equation 2: Final Velocity from Acceleration and Time
text:
Kinematic Equation 2: Final Velocity from Acceleration and Time
We start with the definition of acceleration (\(a = \text{constant}\)):
\[ a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \]
Using simplified notation (\(\Delta v = v - v_0\), \(\Delta t = t\)):
\[ a = \frac{v - v_0}{t} \]
Solving for \(v\):
\[ v = v_0 + at \]






Note


This equation is very useful as it directly links final velocity, initial velocity, acceleration, and time. It shows how much velocity changes due to acceleration over a given time.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Calculating Final Velocity
Problem: An airplane lands with an initial velocity of 70.0 m/s and then accelerates opposite to the motion at 1.50 m/s² for 40.0 s. What is its final velocity?
Strategy:

Identify Knowns: \(v_0 = 70.0\) m/s, \(a = -1.50\) m/s² (negative because opposite to motion), \(t = 40.0\) s.
Identify Unknown: Final velocity, \(v\).
Choose Equation: Use \(v = v_0 + at\).

Solution: \[ v = 70.0 \, \text{m/s} + (-1.50 \, \text{m/s}^2)(40.0 \, \text{s}) \] \[ v = 70.0 \, \text{m/s} - 60.0 \, \text{m/s} = 10.0 \, \text{m/s} \]

Figure 3.19: Airplane slowing down during landing.

The positive final velocity indicates the airplane is still moving forward (in the initial direction), but much slower. This makes intuitive sense for a landing plane.

title: Physics
text:
Insights from \(v = v_0 + at\)
This equation provides useful insights:

Final velocity depends on acceleration magnitude and duration.
If \(a=0\), then \(v=v_0\) (velocity is constant).
If \(a\) is negative (opposite to \(v_0\)), then \(v < v_0\) (slowing down).

These observations align with our physical intuition.

title: Physics
section: Kinematic Equation 3: Final Position with Constant Acceleration
text:
Kinematic Equation 3: Final Position with Constant Acceleration
Combine \(x = x_0 + \bar{v}t\) and \(\bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2}\) and \(v = v_0 + at\).
Substitute \(\bar{v} = v_0 + \frac{1}{2}at\) into \(x = x_0 + \bar{v}t\):
\[ x = x_0 + (v_0 + \frac{1}{2}at)t \]
\[ x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 \]






Important


This is one of the most frequently used kinematic equations. It relates final position to initial position, initial velocity, acceleration, and time.

title: Physics
section: Example: Calculating Displacement of an Accelerating Object
text:
Example: Calculating Displacement of an Accelerating Object
Problem: A dragster accelerates from rest at 26.0 m/s² for 5.56 s. How far does it travel?
Strategy:

Identify Knowns: \(v_0 = 0\) m/s (from rest), \(a = 26.0\) m/s², \(t = 5.56\) s. Assume \(x_0 = 0\).
Identify Unknown: Final position, \(x\).
Choose Equation: Use \(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\).


Figure 3.21: Sketch of an accelerating dragster.

The sketch helps visualize the motion and define the starting position. Since it starts from rest, the \(v_0t\) term simplifies to zero.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution
Solution:
Since \(x_0 = 0\) and \(v_0 = 0\), the equation simplifies to: \[ x = \frac{1}{2}at^2 \]
Substitute the known values: \[ x = \frac{1}{2}(26.0 \, \text{m/s}^2)(5.56 \, \text{s})^2 \] \[ x = \frac{1}{2}(26.0 \, \text{m/s}^2)(30.9136 \, \text{s}^2) \] \[ x = 401.8768 \, \text{m} \approx 402 \, \text{m} \]
Significance: 402 m is approximately a quarter-mile, a standard distance for drag racing, making the answer reasonable. This equation shows displacement depends on the square of time (\(t^2\)) when acceleration is non-zero.

The squared dependence on time means that the distance covered increases rapidly over time when accelerating. For example, in the first half of the time, the car only covers a quarter of the total distance.

title: Physics
section: Kinematic Equation 4: Final Velocity from Distance and Acceleration
text:
Kinematic Equation 4: Final Velocity from Distance and Acceleration
We can derive a fourth useful equation by eliminating time (\(t\)) from the others.
From \(v = v_0 + at\), solve for \(t\): \[ t = \frac{v - v_0}{a} \]
Substitute this \(t\) and \(\bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2}\) into \(x = x_0 + \bar{v}t\): \[ x = x_0 + \left(\frac{v_0 + v}{2}\right)\left(\frac{v - v_0}{a}\right) \]
Rearrange to get: \[ v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0) \]






Important


This equation is powerful because it allows you to find final velocity without knowing the time, or to find displacement without knowing the time.

title: Physics
section: Example: Calculating Final Velocity Without Time
text:
Example: Calculating Final Velocity Without Time
Problem: Calculate the final velocity of the dragster from the previous example (\(a = 26.0\) m/s², \(\Delta x = 402\) m, \(v_0 = 0\)) without using information about time.
Strategy:

Identify Knowns: \(v_0 = 0\) m/s, \(\Delta x = x - x_0 = 402\) m, \(a = 26.0\) m/s².
Identify Unknown: Final velocity, \(v\).
Choose Equation: Use \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\).

Solution: \[ v^2 = (0 \, \text{m/s})^2 + 2(26.0 \, \text{m/s}^2)(402 \, \text{m}) \] \[ v^2 = 0 + 20904 \, \text{m}^2/\text{s}^2 \] \[ v = \sqrt{20904 \, \text{m}^2/\text{s}^2} \approx 144.6 \, \text{m/s} \approx 145 \, \text{m/s} \]

We take the positive square root because the dragster is moving in the positive direction. A velocity of 145 m/s is very fast, equivalent to about 324 mi/h, which is expected for a dragster.

title: Physics
text:
Insights from \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\)
This equation offers additional insights:

Final velocity depends on acceleration and the distance over which it acts.
For a fixed acceleration, if initial velocity doubles, the stopping distance quadruples (\(x \propto v_0^2\)).

This is why high speeds are dangerous; it takes much longer to stop!

title: Physics
text:
Summary of Kinematic Equations (Constant \(a\))
These five equations are fundamental for solving problems with constant acceleration:

\(x = x_0 + \bar{v}t\)
\(\bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2}\)
\(v = v_0 + at\)
\(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\)
\(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\)







Tip


When solving problems, identify your knowns and unknowns.
Choose the equation(s) that allow you to solve for the unknown(s) with the given information.
You need as many independent equations as you have unknowns.

title: Physics
section: Example: Stopping Distance of a Car
text:
Example: Stopping Distance of a Car
Problem: A car travels at 30.0 m/s.

What is the stopping distance on dry concrete (\(a = -7.00\) m/s²)?
What is the stopping distance on wet concrete (\(a = -5.00\) m/s²)?
Repeat, accounting for a 0.500 s reaction time.

Strategy:

Set \(v_0 = 30.0\) m/s, \(v = 0\) m/s (car stops).
For (a) and (b), use \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\).
For (c), first calculate distance traveled during reaction time (constant velocity), then add to braking distance.


Figure 3.22: Sketch for stopping distance.

The sketch helps visualize the initial and final states and the direction of acceleration.
It’s important to use the correct sign for acceleration (negative, as it’s opposite to motion).

Example: Solution (Parts a & b)
Solution (Parts a & b):
Given: \(v_0 = 30.0\) m/s, \(v = 0\) m/s, \(x_0 = 0\).
Equation: \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\)
Rearrange for \(x\): \(x = \frac{v^2 - v_0^2}{2a}\)
(a) Dry Concrete (\(a = -7.00\) m/s²): \[ x_{\text{dry}} = \frac{(0 \, \text{m/s})^2 - (30.0 \, \text{m/s})^2}{2(-7.00 \, \text{m/s}^2)} \] \[ x_{\text{dry}} = \frac{-900 \, \text{m}^2/\text{s}^2}{-14.00 \, \text{m/s}^2} = 64.3 \, \text{m} \]
(b) Wet Concrete (\(a = -5.00\) m/s²): \[ x_{\text{wet}} = \frac{(0 \, \text{m/s})^2 - (30.0 \, \text{m/s})^2}{2(-5.00 \, \text{m/s}^2)} \] \[ x_{\text{wet}} = \frac{-900 \, \text{m}^2/\text{s}^2}{-10.00 \, \text{m/s}^2} = 90.0 \, \text{m} \]

Notice that the stopping distance is significantly longer on wet concrete due to the lower magnitude of acceleration (less effective braking).

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Part c)
Solution (Part c):
During Reaction Time (0.500 s):

Velocity is constant: \(v_0 = 30.0\) m/s, \(a = 0\).
Equation: \(x = x_0 + v_0t\). Assume \(x_0 = 0\). \[ x_{\text{reaction}} = (30.0 \, \text{m/s})(0.500 \, \text{s}) = 15.0 \, \text{m} \]

Total Stopping Distances:

Dry Concrete: \(x_{\text{total, dry}} = x_{\text{reaction}} + x_{\text{dry}} = 15.0 \, \text{m} + 64.3 \, \text{m} = 79.3 \, \text{m}\)
Wet Concrete: \(x_{\text{total, wet}} = x_{\text{reaction}} + x_{\text{wet}} = 15.0 \, \text{m} + 90.0 \, \text{m} = 105.0 \, \text{m}\)


Figure 3.23: Braking distances with and without reaction time.

Reaction time adds a significant distance to the total stopping distance, highlighting its importance in road safety.
This part combines two phases of motion: constant velocity and constant acceleration.

section: Example: Calculating Time to Travel a Distance
text:
Example: Calculating Time to Travel a Distance
Problem: A car merges onto a 200-m ramp. Initial velocity is 10.0 m/s, and acceleration is 2.00 m/s². How long does it take to travel 200 m?
Strategy:

Identify Knowns: \(x_0 = 0\), \(x = 200\) m, \(v_0 = 10.0\) m/s, \(a = 2.00\) m/s².
Identify Unknown: Time, \(t\).
Choose Equation: Use \(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\).


Figure 3.24: Car accelerating on a freeway ramp.

The visual helps to set up the coordinate system and understand the values. The chosen equation includes \(t^2\), indicating a quadratic equation will arise.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution
Solution:
Substitute known values into \(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\): \[ 200 \, \text{m} = 0 + (10.0 \, \text{m/s})t + \frac{1}{2}(2.00 \, \text{m/s}^2)t^2 \] Simplify (and temporarily drop units for the quadratic equation): \[ 200 = 10t + t^2 \] Rearrange into standard quadratic form \(at^2 + bt + c = 0\): \[ t^2 + 10t - 200 = 0 \] Use the quadratic formula \(t = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\): \[ t = \frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{(10)^2 - 4(1)(-200)}}{2(1)} \] \[ t = \frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{100 + 800}}{2} = \frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{900}}{2} = \frac{-10 \pm 30}{2} \] Two solutions:
\(t_1 = \frac{-10 + 30}{2} = \frac{20}{2} = 10.0 \, \text{s}\)
\(t_2 = \frac{-10 - 30}{2} = \frac{-40}{2} = -20.0 \, \text{s}\)
Significance:
A negative time is physically unreasonable in this context, so \(t = 10.0\) s is the correct answer.

Always consider the physical meaning of your mathematical solutions. Discarding negative time values is a common practice in kinematics problems where motion starts at \(t=0\).

Given:

\(a = 20\) m/s²
\(v = 400\) m/s

text:
Two-Body Pursuit Problems
These involve two objects whose motions are interconnected.

The unknown often depends on the motion of both objects.
Strategy: Write separate equations of motion for each object. Then solve them simultaneously for the common unknown (e.g., time or position).


Figure 3.25: Car 1 (accelerating) pursues Car 2 (constant velocity).

The key to two-body problems is identifying a common variable between the two motions, such as time or position, at the point of interest (e.g., when one catches the other).

title: Physics
text:
Example: Cheetah Catching a Gazelle
Problem: A cheetah (\(v_0 = 0\), \(a = 4\) m/s²) spots a gazelle (\(v = 10\) m/s constant) passing at the same instant (\(x_0 = 0\) for both).

How long does it take the cheetah to catch the gazelle?
What is their displacement when the cheetah catches the gazelle?

Strategy:

Define equations of motion for both cheetah and gazelle.
At the moment the cheetah catches the gazelle, their positions (\(x\)) and times (\(t\)) will be the same.
Set their position equations equal to each other to solve for \(t\).


This is a classic pursuit problem. Emphasize that the relative starting position is zero, and the relative final position is zero, meaning their final positions are identical.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Part a)
Solution (Part a): Time to catch

Equation for Gazelle (constant velocity):
\(x_{\text{gazelle}} = x_0 + v_0t\)
Since \(x_0 = 0\) and \(v_0 = \bar{v} = 10\) m/s:
\[ x_{\text{gazelle}} = (10 \, \text{m/s})t \]
Equation for Cheetah (constant acceleration from rest):
\(x_{\text{cheetah}} = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\)
Since \(x_0 = 0\) and \(v_0 = 0\), and \(a = 4\) m/s²:
\[ x_{\text{cheetah}} = \frac{1}{2}(4 \, \text{m/s}^2)t^2 = (2 \, \text{m/s}^2)t^2 \]
Set positions equal and solve for \(t\):
When the cheetah catches the gazelle, \(x_{\text{cheetah}} = x_{\text{gazelle}}\).
\[ (10 \, \text{m/s})t = (2 \, \text{m/s}^2)t^2 \] \[ 10t = 2t^2 \] \[ 2t^2 - 10t = 0 \] \[ 2t(t - 5) = 0 \]
This gives two solutions: \(t = 0\) s (the start) and \(t = 5\) s.
The time it takes to catch the gazelle is \(t = 5\) s.


The \(t=0\) solution simply means they were at the same point at the beginning. The \(t=5\)s solution is when the cheetah actually catches the gazelle.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Solution (Part b)
Solution (Part b): Displacement
To find the displacement, substitute \(t = 5\) s into either equation of motion:

Using Gazelle’s equation: \[ x_{\text{gazelle}} = (10 \, \text{m/s})(5 \, \text{s}) = 50 \, \text{m} \]
Using Cheetah’s equation: \[ x_{\text{cheetah}} = (2 \, \text{m/s}^2)(5 \, \text{s})^2 = (2 \, \text{m/s}^2)(25 \, \text{s}^2) = 50 \, \text{m} \]

Both methods yield the same displacement, as expected.
The cheetah catches the gazelle after both have traveled 50 m.

This confirms the consistency of the solution and the logic of setting the positions equal.

Check Your Understanding 3.6
Problem: A bicycle has a constant velocity of 10 m/s. A person starts from rest and runs to catch up to the bicycle in 30 s when they are at the same position. What is the acceleration of the person?


Given:

Bicycle: \(v_B = 10\) m/s (constant)
Person: \(v_{P0} = 0\) m/s (from rest), \(t = 30\) s
At \(t=30\) s, \(x_B = x_P\) (and assume \(x_{B0}=x_{P0}=0\))


Formulas to use:

Bicycle: \(x_B = v_B t\)
Person: \(x_P = \frac{1}{2}a_P t^2\)
Then set \(x_B = x_P\).



Encourage students to solve this as a two-body pursuit problem. Solution: \(10t = \frac{1}{2}a t^2 \Rightarrow 10(30) = \frac{1}{2}a(30)^2 \Rightarrow 300 = 450a \Rightarrow a = 300/450 = 2/3 \approx 0.67\) m/s².
